{{Infobox book <!-- |italic title = (see above) --> | name = America's Four Gods: What We Say about God-- & what that Says about Us | image = America's Four Gods What We Say about God--and What That Says about Us.jpeg | caption = | author = Paul Froese, Christopher Bader | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | subject = [[God]] | genre = | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | pub_date = 2010 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 978-0-19-534147-8 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''America's Four Gods: What We Say about God-- & what that Says about Us''' is a book published in 2010 by [[Baylor University]] professors Paul Froese and Christopher Bader.<ref name=SeattleTimes2010-10-22> {{cite news | url = http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2013204073_howell23m.html | title = Americans split on the kind of God they believe in | publisher = [[Seattle Times]] | date = 2010-10-22 | accessdate = 2012-05-16 | quote = They show that regardless of religious tradition (Jew, Buddhist, Catholic, Protestant, Muslim), the great divide falls out around belief in four distinct deities: the Authoritative God, who is engaged with the world and judgmental; the Benevolent God, who loves and aids us in spite of our failings; the Critical God, who catalogs our sins but does not punish them (at least not in this life); and the Distant God, who stands apart from the world. Such views shape one's worldview and one's moral, political convictions. | page = | author = Patrick J. Howell }} </ref> The book was based on a 2005 survey of religious views and reports that Americans conception of God fall into four different classes.<ref name=Abc2010-10-07> {{cite news | url = http://abcnews.go.com/WN/book-religion-examines-ways-americans-perceive-god/story?id=11825319#.T7QdcFIpmzU | title = A look at the four ways Americans view God | publisher = [[ABC News]] | date = 2010-10-07 | accessdate = 2012-05-16 | quote = According to a new book called "America's Four Gods" by Paul Froese and Christopher Bader, the way Americans view of God falls into four categories. | page = | author = Dan Harris, Enjoli Francis }} </ref> Further, they report, American's views on political, moral and scientific issues are usually tied to their conception of God.<ref name=USAToday2010-10-07> {{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2010-10-07-1Agod07_CV_N.htm | title = Americans' views of God shape attitudes on key issues | publisher = [[USA Today]] | date = 2010-10-07 | accessdate = 2012-05-16 | quote = Surveys say about nine out of 10 Americans believe in God, but the way we picture that God reveals our attitudes on economics, justice, social morality, war, natural disasters, science, politics, love and more, say Paul Froese and Christopher Bader, sociologists at Baylor University in Waco, Texas. Their new book, America's Four Gods: What We Say About God — And What That Says About Us, examines our diverse visions of the Almighty and why they matter. | page = | author = Cathy Lynn Grossman }} </ref>
The four different conceptions of God described in the book are the ''authoritative God'', the ''benevolent God'', the ''critical God'' and the ''distant God''.<ref name=ChristianityToday2010-11-15> {{cite news | url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2010/november/21.65.html | title = The Divine Divide: The gods of America, and the difference they make | publisher = [[Christianity Today]] | date = 2010-11-15 | accessdate = | quote = Respondents' answers lead the authors to identify four conceptions of God among the American religious public: (1) the authoritative God, who both judges and is closely engaged in the world; (2) the benevolent God, who is "engaged but nonjudgmental"; (3) the critical God, who happens to be judgmental but disengaged; and (4) the distant God, who is neither engaged nor judgmental, and {{sic|could}} care less about how humans muck about. | page = | author = Matthew Lee Anderson }} </ref>
Individuals who conceive of an authoritative God and a benevolent God both see God as taking an interventionist role in believers lives. They differ, however, in how they see God intervening.<ref name=ChristianityToday2010-11-15/> Those who conceive of an authoritative God imagine God intervenes to punish those who lapse from his rules, and are likely to be white males. Those who conceive of a benevolent God imagine God intervenes to rescue and present alternatives, and are likely to be female.
Individuals who conceive of a critical God imagine he does not intervene in individuals lives, but will judge them in an afterlife. Statistically black Americans are more likely to hold this conception.<ref name=ChristianityToday2010-11-15/>
Those who believe in a distant God imagine that God set the entire Universe in motion, but has no engagement with humanity at all.<ref name=ChristianityToday2010-11-15/> Americans who hold this conception are statistically likely to have completed more years of education than those in the other three groups.
Father [[Patrick J. Howell]], a Jesuit writing in ''[[The Seattle Times]]'', noted that the four conceptions of God where represented by followers of [[Judaism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Catholicism]], [[Protestantism]] and [[Islam]].<ref name=SeattleTimes2010-10-22/> Howell wrote: {{quotation|Some would have us believe, Froese and Bader argue, that American society is engaged in a titanic struggle between "true believers" and the "godless." But the two authors note that only 5 percent are atheists, and they identify four, mostly contradictory, views of God as the source for the intractable social and political divisions among Americans.}}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{good article}} [[File:Aberlemnokirkyardcropped.jpg|thumb|300px|The Class II Kirkyard stone c. 800, [[Aberlemno]]]] '''Art in Medieval Scotland''' includes all forms of [[Scottish art|artistic production]] within the modern borders of Scotland, between the fifth century and the adoption of the [[Renaissance in Scotland|Renaissance]] in the early sixteenth century. In the [[early Middle Ages]], there were distinct material cultures evident in the different federations and kingdoms within what is now Scotland. [[Pictish art]] was the only uniquely Scottish Medieval style; it can be seen in the extensive survival of carved stones, particularly in the north and east of the country, which hold a variety of recurring images and patterns. It can also be seen in elaborate metal work that largely survives in buried hoards. Irish-Scots art from the kingdom of [[Dál Riata]] suggests that it was one of the places, as a crossroads between cultures, where the Insular style developed.
[[Insular art]] is the name given to the common style that developed in Britain and Ireland from the eighth century and which became highly influential in continental Europe and contributed to the development of [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] and [[Gothic art|Gothic]] styles. It can be seen in elaborate jewellery, often making extensive use of semi-precious stones, in the heavily carved [[high cross]]es found particularly in the Highlands and Islands, but distributed across the country and particularly in the highly decorated illustrated manuscripts such as the [[Book of Kells]], which may have been begun, or wholly created at the monastic centre of [[Iona]].
Scotland adopted the Romanesque style relatively late and retained and revived elements of its style after the Gothic style had become dominant from the thirteenth century. Much of the best Scottish artwork of the High and Late Middle Ages was either religious in nature or realised in metal and woodwork, and has not survived the impact of time and the Reformation. However, examples of sculpture are extant as part of church architecture, including evidence of elaborate church interiors. From the thirteenth century there are relatively large numbers of monumental effigies. Native craftsmanship can be seen in a variety of items. Visual illustration can be seen in the illumination of charters and occasional survivals of church paintings. Surviving copies of individual portraits are relatively crude, but more impressive are the works or artists commissioned from the continent, particularly the Netherlands.
==Early Middle Ages== {{Main|Celtic art}}
===Pictish stones=== {{Main|Pictish stones}} [[File:DunnichenMeffan.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The [[Dunnichen Stone]], a Class I incised stone, with [[Double disc (Pictish symbol)|double disc and z-rod]], [[Mirror and comb (Pictish symbol)|mirror and comb]] and flower Pictish symbols]] About 250 Pictish stones survive and have been assigned by scholars to three classes.<ref>J. N. G. Ritchie and A. Ritchie, ''Scotland, Archaeology and Early History'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2nd edn., 1991), {{ISBN|0748602917}}, pp. 161–5.</ref> Class I stones are those thought to date to the period up to the seventh century and are the most numerous group. The stones are largely unshaped and include incised symbols of animals such as fish and the [[Pictish beast]], everyday objects such as mirrors, combs and tuning forks and abstract symbols defined by names including V-rod, double disc and Z-rod. They are found between from the [[Firth of Forth]] to [[Shetland]]. The greatest concentrations are in Sutherland, around modern Inverness and Aberdeen. Good examples include the [[Dunrobin Castle|Dunrobin]] (Sutherland) and [[Aberlemno]] stones ([[Angus, Scotland|Angus]]).<ref name=Graham-Campbell1998pp.7-8>[[James Graham-Campbell|J. Graham-Campbell]] and C. E. Batey, ''Vikings in Scotland: an Archaeological Survey'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1998), {{ISBN|0748606416}}, pp. 7–8.</ref>
Class II stones are carefully shaped slabs dating after the arrival of Christianity in the eighth and ninth centuries, with a cross on one face and a wide range of symbols on the reverse. In smaller numbers than Class I stones, they predominate in southern Pictland, in Perth, Angus and Fife. Good examples include [[Glamis]] 2, which contains a finely executed [[Celtic cross]] on the main face with two opposing male figures, a centaur, cauldron, deer head and a triple disc symbol and Cossans, Angus, which shows a high-prowed Pictish boat with oarsmen and a figure facing forward in the prow.<ref name=Graham-Campbell1998pp.7-8/> Class III stones are thought to overlap chronologically with Class II stones.<ref name=Graham-Campbell1998pp.7-8/> Most are elaborately shaped and incised cross-slabs, some with figurative scenes, but lacking idiomatic Pictish symbols. They are widely distributed but predominate in the southern Pictish areas.<ref name=Graham-Campbell1998pp.7-8/>
===Pictish metalwork=== Items of metalwork have been found throughout Pictland. The earlier Picts appear to have had a considerable amount of silver available, probably from raiding further south, or the payment of subsidies to keep them from doing so. The very large hoard of late Roman [[hacksilver]] found at [[Traprain Law]] may have originated in either way. The largest hoard of early Pictish metalwork was found in 1819 at Norrie's Law in Fife, but unfortunately much was dispersed and melted down.<ref name=Youngs1989pp26-8>S. Youngs, ed., ''"The Work of Angels", Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork, 6th–9th centuries AD'' (London: British Museum Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0714105546}}, pp. 26–8.</ref> Over ten heavy silver chains, some over {{convert|0.5|m|ft}} long, have been found from this period; the double-linked [[Whitecleuch Chain]] is one of only two that have a penannular ring, with symbol decoration including enamel, which shows how these were probably used as "choker" necklaces.<ref name=Youngs1989pp26-8/> The [[St Ninian's Isle]] Treasure of 28 silver and silver-gilt objects, contains perhaps the best collection of late Pictish forms, from the Christian period, when Pictish metalwork style, as with stone-carving, gradually merged with Insular, Anglo-Saxon and Viking styles.<ref>L. R. Laing, ''Later Celtic Art in Britain and Ireland'' (London: Osprey Publishing, 1987), {{ISBN|0852638744}}, p. 37.</ref>
===Irish-Scots art=== {{See also|Irish art}} [[File:Hunterston BroochDSCF6363.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The front of the [[Hunterston Brooch]], found near [[Hunterston]], [[North Ayrshire]], which shows Irish elements of style and may have been made in the kingdom of [[Dál Riata]]]] [[Thomas Charles-Edwards]] has suggested that the kingdom of Dál Riata was a cross-roads between the artistic styles of the Picts and those of Ireland, with which the Scots settlers in what is now Argyll kept close contacts. This can be seen in representations found in excavations of the fortress of Dunadd, which combine Pictish and Irish elements.<ref>T. M. Charles-Edwards, ''Early Christian Ireland'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000), {{ISBN|0521363950}}, pp. 331–2.</ref> This included extensive evidence for the production of high status jewellery and moulds from the seventh century that indicate the production of pieces similar to the [[Hunterston brooch]], found in Ayrshire, which may have been made in Dál Riata, but with elements that suggest Irish origins. These and other finds, including a trumpet spiral decorated hanging bowl disc and a stamped animal decoration (or pressblech), perhaps from a bucket or drinking horn, indicate the ways in which Dál Riata was one of the locations where the Insular style was developed.<ref name=Lane2001>A. Lane, [http://www.britarch.ac.uk/ba/ba62/feat1.shtml "Citadel of the first Scots"], ''British Archaeology'', 62, December 2001. Retrieved 2 December 2010.</ref> In the eighth and ninth centuries the Pictish elite adopted true penannular [[brooch]]es with lobed terminals from Ireland. Some older Irish [[pseudo-penannular]] brooches were adapted to the Pictish style, for example the Breadalbane Brooch (British Museum). The eighth century [[Monymusk Reliquary]] has elements of Pictish and Irish style.<ref name=Youngs1989pp109-1123>S. Youngs, ed., ''"The Work of Angels", Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork, 6th–9th centuries AD'' (London: British Museum Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0714105546}}, pp. 109–113.</ref>
===Early Anglo-Saxon art=== {{Main|Anglo-Saxon art}} Early examples of Anglo-Saxon art are largely metalwork, particularly bracelets, clasps and jewellery, that has survived in pagan burials and in exceptional items such as the intricately carved whalebone [[Franks Casket]], thought to have been produced in [[Northumbria]] in the early eighth century, which combines pagan, classical and Christian motifs.<ref>[[Charles Reginald Dodwell|C. R. Dodwell]], ''Anglo-Saxon Art: A New Perspective'' (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1982), {{ISBN|071900926X}}, pp. 2–4.</ref> There is only one known pagan burial in Scotland, at [[Dalmeny]] Midlothian, which contains a necklace of beads similar to those found in mid-seventh-century southern England. Other isolated finds include a gold object from Dalmeny, shaped like a truncated pyramid, with [[filigree]] and [[garnet]], similar to sword harness mounts found at [[Sutton Hoo]]. There is also a bun-shaped loom from [[Yetholm]], Roxburghshire and a ring with an Anglian [[runes|runic]] inscription. From eastern Scotland there is a seventh-century sword [[Hilt#Pommel|pommel]] from [[Culbin Sands]], Moray and the [[Burghead]] drinking horn mount.<ref>L. Laing, ''The Archaeology of Late Celtic Britain and Ireland C. 400–1200 AD'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1975), {{ISBN|0416823602}}, p. 28.</ref> After [[Christianisation of Scotland|Christianisation]] in the seventh century artistic styles in Northumbria, which then reached to the Firth of Forth, interacted with those in Ireland and what is now Scotland to become part of the common style historians have identified as Insular or Hiberno-Saxon.<ref>C. E Karkov, ''The Art of Anglo-Saxon England'' (Boydell Press, 2011), {{ISBN|1843836289}}, p. 5.</ref>
===Insular art=== {{Main|Insular art}} [[File:KellsFol292rIncipJohn.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The opening page from the [[Gospel of John]] from the [[Book of Kells]], usually thought to have been made in [[Iona]].]] Insular art, or Hiberno-Saxon art, is the name given to the common style produced in Scotland, Britain and Anglo-Saxon England from the seventh century, with the combining of Celtic and Anglo-Saxon forms.<ref>H. Honour and J. Fleming, ''A World History of Art'' (London: Macmillan), {{ISBN|0333371852}}, pp. 244–7.</ref> Surviving examples of Insular art are found in metalwork, carving, but mainly in [[illuminated manuscript]]s. In manuscripts surfaces are highly decorated with intricate patterning, with no attempt to give an impression of depth, volume or recession. The best examples include the [[Book of Kells]], which may have been wholly or partly created in Iona, and the [[Book of Durrow]], which may be from Ireland or Northumbria. [[Carpet pages]] are a characteristic feature of Insular manuscripts, although [[historiated initial]]s (an Insular invention), [[canon table]]s and figurative miniatures, especially [[Evangelist portrait]]s, are also common. The finest era of the style was brought to an end by the disruption to monastic centres and aristocratic life of the Viking raids in the late eighth century.<ref>C. R. Dodwell, ''The Pictorial Arts of the West, 800–1200'' (Yale UP, 1993), {{ISBN|0300064934}}, pp. 85 and 90.</ref>
Christianity discouraged the burial of grave goods so the majority of examples of insular metalwork that survive from the Christian period have been found in archaeological contexts that suggest they were rapidly hidden, lost or abandoned.<ref>C. R. Dodwell, ''Anglo-Saxon Art, a New Perspective'' (Manchester:Manchester University Press, 1982), {{ISBN|071900926X}}, p. 4.</ref> There are a few exceptions, notably portable [[shrine]]s ("[[cumdach]]s") for books or [[relic]]s, several of which have been continuously owned, mostly by churches on the Continent—though the [[Monymusk Reliquary]] has always been in Scotland.<ref>S. Youngs, ed., ''"The Work of Angels", Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork'' (London: British Museum Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0714105546}}, pp. 134–140.</ref> The highest quality survivals are either secular jewellery, the largest and most elaborate pieces probably for male wearers, tableware or altarware. The finest church pieces were probably made by secular workshops, often attached to a royal household, though other pieces were made by monastic workshops.<ref>S. Youngs, ed., ''"The Work of Angels", Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork'' (London: British Museum Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0714105546}}, pp. 15–16.</ref> There are a number of large brooches, each of their designs is wholly individual in detail, and the workmanship is varied. Many elements of the designs can be directly related to elements used in manuscripts. Surviving stones used in decoration are semi-precious ones, with [[amber]] and [[rock crystal]] among the commonest, and some [[garnet]]s. Coloured glass, [[Vitreous enamel|enamel]] and [[millefiori]] glass, probably imported, are also used.<ref>S. Youngs, ed., ''"The Work of Angels", Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork'' (London: British Museum Press, 1989), {{ISBN|0714105546}}, pp. 72–115, and 170–174 and D. M. Wilson, ''Anglo-Saxon Art: From The Seventh Century To The Norman Conquest'' (Overlook Press, 1984), pp. 113–114 and 120–130.</ref> None of the major insular manuscripts, like the Book of Kells, have preserved their elaborate jewelled metal covers, but documentary evidence indicates that these were as spectacular as the few remaining continental examples.<ref>R. G. Calkins, ''Illuminated Books of the Middle Ages'' (Ithaca, New York: Cornell University Press 1983), pp. 57–60.</ref>
[[File:Monymusk ReliquaryDSCF6383.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Monymusk Reliquary]], made c. 750]] The most significant survivals in sculpture are in [[High cross]]es, large free-standing stone crosses, usually carved in relief with patterns, biblical iconography and occasionally inscriptions. The tradition may have begun in Ireland or Anglo-Saxon England and then spread to Scotland.<ref name=Koch2006pp915-19>J. T. Koch, ''Celtic Culture: A Historical Encyclopedia, Volumes 1–5'' (ABC-CLIO, 2006), {{ISBN|1851094407}}, pp. 915–19.</ref> They are found throughout the British Isles and often feature a stone ring around the intersection, forming a [[Celtic cross]], apparently an innovation of Celtic Christianity, that may have begun at [[Iona]].<ref>D. M. Wilson, ''Anglo-Saxon Art: From The Seventh Century To The Norman Conquest'' (Overlook Press), 1984, p. 118.</ref> Distribution in Scotland is heaviest in the Highlands and Islands and they can be dated to the period c. 750 to 1150.<ref name=Koch2006pp915-19/> All the surviving crosses are of stone, but there are indications that large numbers of wooden crosses may also have existed. In Scotland biblical iconography is less common than in Ireland, but the subject of [[King David]] is relatively frequently depicted. In the east the influence of Pictish sculpture can be seen, in areas of Viking occupation and settlement, crosses for the tenth to the twelfth centuries have distinctive Scandinavian patterns, often mixed with native styles. Important examples dated to the eighth century include St Martin's Cross on Iona, the [[Kildalton Cross]] from the Hebrides and the Anglo-Saxon [[Ruthwell Cross]].<ref name=Koch2006pp915-19/> Through the [[Hiberno-Scottish mission]] to the continent, insular art was highly influential on subsequent European Medieval art, especially the decorative elements of [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] and [[Gothic art|Gothic]] styles.<ref>G. Henderson, ''Early Medieval Art'' (London: Penguin, 1972), pp. 63–71.</ref>
===Viking age art=== {{See also|Viking Age art}} [[File:UigChessmen SelectionOfKings.jpg|thumb|Some of the [[Lewis chessmen]]]] Viking art avoided naturalism, favouring stylised animal motifs to create its ornamental patterns. Ribbon-interlace was important and plant motifs became fashionable in the tenth and eleventh centuries.<ref>J. Graham-Campbell and C. E. Batey, ''Vikings in Scotland: an Archaeological Survey'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1998), {{ISBN|0748606416}}, p. 34.</ref> Most Scottish artefacts come from 130 "pagan" burials in the north and west from the mid-ninth to the mid-tenth centuries.<ref>M. Carver, ''The Cross Goes North: Processes of Conversion in Northern Europe, AD 300–1300'' (Boydell Press, 2006), {{ISBN|1843831252}}, p. 219.</ref> These include jewellery, weapons and occasional elaborate high status items.<ref>J. Jesch, ''Women in the Viking Age'' (Boydell & Brewer, 1991), {{ISBN|0851153607}}, p. 14.</ref> Amongst the most impressive of these is the [[Scar boat burial]], on Orkney, which contained an elaborate sword, quiver with arrows, a brooch, bone comb, gaming pieces and the Scar Dragon Plaque, made from whalebone, most of which were probably made in Scandinavia.<ref>K. Holman, ''The Northern [I. E. Northern] Conquest: Vikings in Britain and Ireland'' (Signal Books, 2007), {{ISBN|1904955347}}, p. 137.</ref> From the west, another boat burial at Kiloron Bay in [[Colonsay]] revealed a sword, shield, iron cauldron and enamelled scales, which may be Celtic in origin.<ref>L. Laing, ''The Archaeology of Late Celtic Britain and Ireland C. 400–1200 AD'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1975), {{ISBN|0416823602}}, p. 201.</ref> A combination of Viking and Celtic styles can be see in a [[penannular brooch]] from Pierowall in Orkney, which has a Pictish-style looped pin. It is about two inches in diameter, with traces of gilding, and probably housed a piece of amber surrounded by interweaving ribbons.<ref>W. Nolan, L. Ronayne and M. Dunlevy, eds, ''Donegal: History & Society: Interdisciplinary Essays on the History of an Irish County'' (Geography, 1995), {{ISBN|0906602459}}, p. 96.</ref> After the conversion to Christianity, from the tenth to the twelfth centuries, stone crosses and cross-slabs in Viking occupied areas of the Highlands and Islands were carved with successive styles of Viking ornament.<ref>J. Koch, ''Celtic Culture: Aberdeen Breviary-Celticism'' (ABC-CLIO, 2006), {{ISBN|1851094407}}. p. 918.</ref> They were frequently mixed with native interlace and animal patterns. Examples include the eleventh-century cross-slab from Dóid Mhàiri on the island of [[Islay]], where the plant motifs on either side of the cross-shaft are based upon the [[Ringerike style]] of Viking art.<ref>J. Graham-Campbell and C. E. Batey. ''Vikings in Scotland: an Archaeological Survey'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1998), {{ISBN|0748606416}}, p. 90.</ref> The most famous artistic find from modern Scotland, the [[Lewis Chessmen]], from [[Uig, Lewis|Uig]], were probably made in [[Trondheim]] in Norway, but contain some decoration that may have been influenced by Celtic patterns.<ref>M. MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'' (London: Thames and Hudson, 2000), {{ISBN|0500203334}}, p. 31.</ref>
==Late Middle Ages== ===Architecture and sculpture=== {{Main|Architecture in Medieval Scotland}} [[File:St Bride's Church Douglas - Archibald.jpg|thumb|left|Effigy of [[Archibald Douglas, 5th Earl of Douglas|Archibald, 5th earl of Douglas]] (1390–1439) in St Bride's Church, [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire|Douglas]]]] Architectural evidence suggests that, while the Romanesque style peaked in much of Europe in the later eleventh and early twelfth century, it was still reaching Scotland in the second half of the twelfth century<ref>R. N. Swanson, ''The Twelfth-Century Renaissance'' (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1999), {{ISBN|0719042569}}, p. 155.</ref> and was revived in the late fifteenth century, perhaps as a reaction to the [[English Gothic architecture|English perpendicular]] style that had come to dominate.<ref>T. M. Devine and J. Wormald, ''The Oxford Handbook of Modern Scottish History'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012), {{ISBN|0191624330}}, p. 190.</ref> Much of the best Scottish artwork of the High and Late Middle Ages was either religious in nature or realised in metal and woodwork and has not survived the impact of time and the Reformation.<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/> However, examples of sculpture are extant as part of church architecture, a small number of significant crafted items have also survived and, for the end of the period, there is evidence of painting, particularly the extensive commissioning of works in the Low Countries and France.<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9"/>
The interiors of churches were often more elaborate before the Reformation, with highly decorated sacrament houses, like the ones surviving at Deskford and Kinkell.<ref name=Whyte&Whyte1991p117>I. D. Whyte and K. A. Whyte, ''The Changing Scottish landscape, 1500–1800'' (London: Taylor & Francis, 1991), {{ISBN|0415029929}}, p. 117.</ref> The carvings at [[Rosslyn Chapel]], created in the mid-fifteenth century, elaborately depicting the progression of the [[seven deadly sins]], are considered some of the finest in the Gothic style.<ref>S. H. Rigby, ''A Companion to Britain in the Later Middle Ages'' (London: Wiley-Blackwell, 2003), {{ISBN|0631217851}}, p. 532.</ref> Monumental effigies began to appear in churches from the thirteenth century and they were usually fully coloured and gilded. Many were founders and patrons of churches and chapels, including members of the clergy, knights and often their wives. In contrast to England, where the fashion for stone-carved monuments gave way to brass etchings, they continued to be produced until the end of the Medieval period, with the largest group dating from the fifteenth century,<ref>R. Brydall, ''The Monumental Effigies of Scotland: From the Thirteenth to the Fifteenth Century'' (Kessinger Publishing, 1895, rpt. 2010) {{ISBN|1169232329}}.</ref><ref>K. Stevenson, ''Chivalry and Knighthood in Scotland, 1424–1513'' (Boydell Press, 2006), {{ISBN|1843831929}}, pp. 125–8.</ref> including the very elaborate Douglas tombs in the town of [[Douglas, South Lanarkshire|Douglas]].<ref name=Whyte&Whyte1991p117/> Sometimes the best continental artists were employed, as for [[Robert I of Scotland|Robert I]]'s elaborate tomb in [[Dunfermline Abbey]], which was made in his lifetime by the Parisian sculptor Thomas of Chartres, but of which only fragments now survive.<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/> The greatest group of surviving sculpture from this period are from the West Highlands, beginning in the fourteenth century on Iona under the patronage of the [[Lord of the Isles|Lordship of the Isles]] and continuing until the Reformation. Common motifs were ships, swords, harps and Romanesque vine leaf tracery with Celtic elements.<ref>M. MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'' (London: Thames and Hudson, 2000), {{ISBN|0500203334}}, pp. 34–5.</ref>{{clear}}
===Decorative arts=== {{Main|Sculpture in Scotland}} [[File:Financrozier2.jpg|thumb|upright|The 12th century "Loch Shiel Crozier Drop", hollow for a relic, with the bust of a king.<ref>V. Glenn, ''Romanesque and Gothic: Decorative Metalwork and Ivory Carvings in the Museum of Scotland'' (National Museums of Scotland, 2003), {{ISBN|1901663558}}, pp. 105–106.</ref>]] Survivals from late Medieval church fittings and objects in Scotland are exceptionally rare even compared to those from comparable areas like England or Norway, probably because of the thoroughness of their destruction in the [[Scottish Reformation]]. The Scottish elite and church now participated in a culture stretching across Europe, and many objects that do survive are imported, such as [[Limoges enamel]]s.<ref>Glenn, 1–4; Chapter III on enamels</ref> It is often difficult to decide the country of creation of others, as work in international styles was produced in Scotland, along with pieces retaining more distinctive local styles.
Two secular small chests with carved whalebone panels and metal fittings illustrate some aspects of the Scottish arts. The Eglington and Fife Caskets are very similar and were probably made by the same workshop around 1500, as boxes for valuables such as jewellery or documents. The overall form of the caskets follows French examples, and the locks and metal bands are decorated in Gothic style with "simple decorations of [[fleuron (architectural)|fleuron]]s and debased [[egg and dart]]" while the whalebone panels are carved in [[relief]] with a late form of Insular interwoven [[strapwork]] characteristic of late Medieval West Scotland.<ref>Glenn, 147, 186–191; both now [[Museum of Scotland]]</ref>
Key examples of native craftsmanship on items include the [[Bute mazer]], the earliest surviving drinking cup of its type, made of maple-wood and with elaborate silver-gilt ornamentation, dated to around 1320.<ref>Glenn, 34–38, and 16th century cover, 191–192</ref> The Savernake Horn was probably made for the earl of Moray in the fourteenth century and looted by the English in the mid-sixteenth century.<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9>B. Webster, ''Medieval Scotland: the Making of an Identity'' (St. Martin's Press, 1997), {{ISBN|0333567617}}, pp. 127–9.</ref> A few significant [[reliquaries]] survive from West Scotland, examples of the habit of the [[Celtic church]] of treating the possessions rather than the bones of saints as [[relic]]s. As in Irish examples these were partly reworked and elaborated at intervals over a long period. These are St Fillan's Crozier and its "Coigreach" or [[reliquary]], between them with elements from each century from the eleventh to the fifteenth, the [[Guthrie, Angus|Guthrie]] Bell Shrine, Iona, twelfth to fifteenth century, and the Kilmichael Glassary Bell Shrine, Argyll, mid-twelfth century.<ref>Glenn, 92–115, all Museum of Scotland; MacDonald, ''Scottish Art'' (London: Thames and Hudson, 2000), {{ISBN|0500203334}}, p. 32.</ref> The Skye Chess piece is a single elaborate piece in carved [[walrus]] ivory, with two warriors carrying heraldic shields in a framework of openwork vegetation. It is thought to be Scottish, of the mid-thirteenth century, with aspects similar to both English and Norwegian pieces.<ref>Glenn, 146–147, 178–181; now Museum of Scotland</ref>
One of the largest groups of surviving works of art are the seal matrices that appear to have entered Scottish usage with feudalism in the reign of David I, beginning at the royal court and among his Anglo-Norman vassals and then by about 1250 they began to spread to the [[Gaelicisation|Gaelicised]] areas of the country. They would be made compulsory for barons of the king in a statute of 1401<ref>Glenn, 116–144; C. J. Neville, ''Land, Law and People in Medieval Scotland'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2010), {{ISBN|0748639586}}, pp. 83–99.</ref> and seal matrices show very high standards of skill and artistry.<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/> Examples of items that were probably the work of continental artists include the delicate hanging lamp in St. John's Kirk in [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]], the vestments and hangings in Holyrood<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9"/> and the Medieval maces of the Universities of [[University of St Andrews|St Andrews]] and [[Glasgow university|Glasgow]].<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/>
===Illumination and painting=== [[File:Trinity Altarpiece.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Trinity Altarpiece]], attributed to Flemish artist [[Hugo van der Goes]] for the [[Trinity College Kirk]] in Edinburgh, Scotland, in the late fifteenth century]] Manuscript illumination continued into the late Middle Ages, moving from elaborate gospels to charters, like that confirming the rights of [[Kelso Abbey]] from 1159.<ref>R. Brydall, ''Art in Scotland: its Origins and Progress'' (Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1889), p. 17.</ref> Very little painting from Scottish churches survives. There is only one surviving [[Doom painting]] in Scotland, at [[Guthrie, Angus|Guthrie]] near [[Arbroath]], which may have been painted by the same artist as the elaborate crucifixion and other paintings at Foulis Easter, eighteen miles away.<ref>M. R. Apted and W. R. Robinson, [http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/arch-352-1/dissemination/pdf/vol_095/95_262_279.pdf "Late fifteenth century church painting from Guthrie and Foulis Easter"], ''Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland'', vol. 95 (1964), pp. 262–79.</ref> As in England, the monarchy may have had model portraits of royalty used for copies and reproductions, but the versions of native royal portraits that survive are generally crude by continental standards.<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9">J. Wormald, ''Court, Kirk, and Community: Scotland, 1470–1625'' (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 1991), {{ISBN|0748602763}}, pp. 57–9.</ref> Much more impressive are the works or artists imported from the continent, particularly the Netherlands, generally considered the centre of painting in the [[Northern Renaissance]].<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9"/> The products of these connections included a fine portrait of [[William Elphinstone]], [[Bishop of Aberdeen]] (1488–1514);<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/> the images of St Catherine and St John brought to [[Dunkeld]]; [[Hugo van Der Goes]]'s altarpiece for the [[Trinity College Kirk|Trinity College Church in Edinburgh]], commissioned by [[James III of Scotland|James III]], and the work after which the Flemish [[Master of James IV of Scotland]] is named.<ref name="Wormald1991pp57-9"/> There are also a relatively large number of elaborate devotional books from the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries, usually produced in the Low Countries and France for Scottish patrons, including the prayer book commissioned by [[Robert Blackadder]], [[Bishop of Glasgow]], between 1484 and 1492<ref name=Webster1997pp127-9/> and the Flemish illustrated [[book of hours]], known as the [[Hours of James IV of Scotland]], given by [[James IV of Scotland|James IV]] to [[Margaret Tudor]] and described as "perhaps the finest medieval manuscript to have been commissioned for Scottish use".<ref>D. H. Caldwell, ed., ''Angels, Nobles and Unicorns: Art and Patronage in Medieval Scotland'' (Edinburgh: National Museum of Scotland, 1982), p. 84.</ref>{{clear}}

The [[British Academy]] presents 18 awards and medals to recognise achievement in the humanities and social sciences.
== Overview == The British Academy currently awards 18 prizes and medals:<ref>{{cite web|title=Prizes and Medals|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/prizes-and-medals|website=The British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref>
General awards: * [[The British Academy Medal|British Academy Medal]] (for academic research that has "transformed understanding" of a field of the humanities or social sciences) * [[President's Medal (British Academy)|The President's Medal]] (for "outstanding service" to the humanities or social sciences) * [[Leverhulme Medal (British Academy)|Leverhulme Medal and Prize]] (for "significant contribution to knowledge or understanding" in a field of the humanities or social sciences)
Discipline-specific awards: {{div col}} * [[Brian Barry Prize in Political Science]] * [[Burkitt Medal for Biblical Studies]] * [[Derek Allen Prize]] (for numismatics, Celtic studies or musicology) * [[Edward Ullendorff Medal]] (for Semitic languages and Ethiopian studies) * [[Grahame Clark Medal]] (for prehistoric archaeology) * [[Kenyon Medal]] (for classical studies and archaeology) * [[Landscape Archaeology Medal]] * [[Nayef Al-Rodhan Prize]] (for global cultural understanding) * [[Neil and Saras Smith Medal for Linguistics]] * [[Peter Townsend Prize]] (for the sociology of poverty, ageing or health) * [[Rose Mary Crawshay Prize]] (for English literature scholarship; women only) * [[Serena Medal]] (for Italian studies) * [[Sir Israel Gollancz Prize]] (for English literature scholarship) * [[Wiley Prize in Economics]] * [[Wiley Prize in Psychology]]
{{div col end}}
== Prizes and medals == ===Brian Barry Prize in Political Science=== The '''Brian Barry Prize in Political Science''' is awarded jointly by the British Academy, the [[Cambridge University Press]], and the ''[[British Journal of Political Science]]''. It was named in honour of [[Brian Barry]] and first awarded in 2014. It is awarded annually to an individual or group "for excellence in political science, as displayed in an unpublished essay". The prize is £2500 and the winning essay is published in the ''British Journal of Political Science''.<ref name="Brian Barry">{{cite web|title=Brian Barry Prize in Political Science|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/brian-barry-prize-political-science|website=British Academy|accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="New">{{cite web|title=A New Prize In Political Science: The Brian Barry Prize|url=https://www1.essex.ac.uk/government/research/bjps/brian_barry_prize.pdf|website=University of Essex|publisher=Cambridge Journals|accessdate=31 July 2017|format=pdf}}</ref>
'''List of Recipients:''' * 2014: Dr [[Helder De Schutter]] and Dr [[Lea Ypi]], for 'Mandatory Citizenship for Immigrants'<ref>{{cite journal|last1=De Schutter|first1=Helder|last2=Ypi|first2=Lea|title=The British Academy Brian Barry Prize Essay: mandatory citizenship for immigrants|journal=British Journal of Political Science|date=2015|volume=45|issue=2|pages=235–251|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/64921/|accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref> * 2015: Dr [[Parashar Kulkarni]], for 'Are There Cultural Prerequisites to Effective Property Rights?: Evidence from Inheritance Rights of Widows in Colonial India'<ref name="ceremony 2015">{{cite web|title=Prizes and Medals ceremony 2015|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/events/prizes-and-medals-ceremony-2015|website=British Academy|accessdate=31 July 2017|date=29 September 2017}}</ref> * 2016: Professor [[William Roberts Clark]], Professor [[Matt Golder]], and Professor [[Sona N. ===British Academy Medal=== {{main|British Academy Medal}} The '''British Academy Medal''' was established in 2013. It is awarded annually "for academic research that has transformed understanding in a field of the humanities and social sciences".<ref>{{cite web|title=British Academy launches medal for landmark research|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/news/british-academy-launches-medal-landmark-research|website=British Academy|accessdate=30 July 2017|date=14 November 2013}}</ref>
===Burkitt Medal=== {{main|Burkitt Medal}}
The '''Burkitt Medal for Biblical Studies''' was established in 1923. It is awarded annually "in recognition of special service to [[Biblical studies|Biblical Studies]]", with the area of study alternating between the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament.<ref>{{cite web|title=Burkitt Medal for Biblical Studies|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/burkitt-medal-biblical-studies|website=British Academy|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref>
=== Derek Allen Prize === The '''Derek Allen Prize''' was founded in 1976 to honour [[Derek Allen]], FBA, who was secretary (1969–73) and treasurer (1973–75) of the British Academy; it was established by his widow and sons to recognise outstanding scholarly achievement in Allen's principal interests: [[numismatics]], [[Celtic studies]] and [[musicology]]. Although awarded annually, the prize rotates between the three disciplines. Recipients are awarded £400.<ref name=":1">[https://www.britac.ac.uk/derek-allen-prize "Derek Allen Prize"], ''British Academy''. Retrieved 13 May 2018.</ref>

=== Edward Ullendorff Medal === The '''Edward Ullendorff Medal''' was created in 2012 to honour Professor [[Edward Ullendorff]], FBA, who had died the previously year; its establishment was supported by his widow. Award annually, the medal recognises "scholarly distinction and achievements in the field of [[Semitic languages|Semitic Languages]] and [[Ethiopian Studies]]".<ref name=":0">[https://www.britac.ac.uk/edward-ullendorff-medal "Edward Ullendorff Medal"], ''British Academy''. Retrieved 13 May 2018.</ref>
'''List of recipients:'''<ref name=":0" />
* 2018: Professor [[John Huehnergard]], University Texas Austin<ref name="winners 2018"/> * 2017: Dr [[Veronika Six]], University of Hamburg. * 2016: Dr [[Sebastian Brock]], FBA, University of Oxford. * 2015: Dr [[Siegbert Uhlig]], University of Hamburg. * 2014: Professor [[David Appleyard]], School of African and Oriental Studies. * 2013: Professor [[Getatchew Haile]], FBA, Hill Museum & Manuscript Library of Saint John's University, USA. * 2012: Professor [[Simon Hopkins]], FBA, Hebrew University, Jerusalem.
=== Grahame Clark Medal === {{main|Grahame Clark Medal}}
The '''Grahame Clark Medal''' endowed in 1992 by [[Sir Grahame Clark]] and first awarded in 1993. It is awarded every two years "for academic achievement involving recent contributions to the study of prehistoric archaeology".<ref>{{cite web|title=Grahame Clark Medal|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/grahame-clark-medal|website=The British Academy|accessdate=11 October 2017}}</ref>
===Kenyon Medal=== {{main|Kenyon Medal}}
The '''Kenyon Medal''' was endowed by [[Sir Frederic Kenyon]] and awarded for the first time in 1957. It is awarded every two years "in recognition of work in the fields of classical studies and archaeology".<ref>{{cite web|title=Kenyon Medal|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/kenyon-medal|website=British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref>
===Landscape Archaeology Medal=== The '''Landscape Archaeology Medal''' is awarded every two years "for distinguished achievements in landscape archaeology". It was first awarded in 2007.<ref name="Landscape">{{cite web|title=Landscape Archaeology Medal|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/landscape-archaeology-medal|website=British Academy|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref>
'''List of Recipients:'''
* 2007: Professor Andrew Fleming * 2009: Professor [[Tony Wilkinson]] * 2011: Dr Conor Newman * 2013: Christopher Taylor * 2015: Dr David Hall * 2017: Professor Tom Williamson, "for his significant contribution to the study of landscape history and archaeology"<ref name="winners 2017">{{cite web|title=Prize and medal winners 2017|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/prize-and-medal-winners-2017|website=The British Academy|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref>
===Leverhulme Medal and Prize=== {{main|Leverhulme Medal (British Academy)}} The '''Leverhulme Medal and Prize''' was created 2002 and is sponsored by [[The Leverhulme Trust]]. It is awarded every three years "for significant contribution to knowledge and understanding in a field within the humanities and social sciences". It is worth £5000.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leverhulme Medal & Prize|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/leverhulme-medal-prize|website=British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref>

===Neil and Saras Smith Medal for Linguistics=== The '''Neil and Saras Smith Medal for Linguistics''' is awarded annually to an individual for "for lifetime achievement in the scholarly study of linguistics". It was established by [[Neil Smith (linguist)|Neil Smith]] in 2013, and first awarded in 2014.<ref name="Neil & Saras">{{cite web|title=Neil & Saras Smith Medal for Linguistics|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/neil-saras-smith-medal-linguistics|website=British Academy|accessdate=30 July 2017}}</ref>

=== Peter Townsend Prize === The '''Peter Townsend Prize''' was created in 2011 to honour the sociologist Professor [[Peter Townsend (sociologist)|Peter Townsend]], FBA, who had died in 2009. The prize is awarded biennially to recognise "outstanding work with policy relevance on a topic to which Townsend made a major contribution." Nominations are made for "a published work with policy relevance and academic merit on poverty and inequality; ageing and the lives of older people; disability and inequalities in health." The prize is awarded with £2,000.<ref name=":3">[https://www.britac.ac.uk/peter-townsend-prize "Peter Townsend Prize"], ''British Academy''. Retrieved 13 May 2018.</ref>

===President's Medal=== {{main|President's Medal (British Academy)}}
The '''President's Medal''' is awarded annually by the British Academy to up to five individuals or organisations for "outstanding service to the cause of the humanities and social sciences". It was first award in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=The British Academy President's Medal|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/british-academy-presidents-medal|website=British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref>
===Rose Mary Crawshay Prize=== {{main|Rose Mary Crawshay Prize}} The '''Rose Mary Crawshay Prize''' was created in 1888 as '''The Byron, Shelley, Keats In Memoriam Yearly Prize Fund''' by [[Rose Mary Crawshay]] (1828–1907). In 1914, the fund was transferred to the British Academy. The newly renamed Rose Mary Crawshay Prize was first awarded in 1916.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rose Mary Crawshay Prize|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/rose-mary-crawshay-prize|website=British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref> It is awarded annually "for a historical or critical work on any subject connected with English Literature by a woman of any nationality" and is worth £500.<ref name="2016 winners">{{cite web|title=British Academy announces 2016 prizes and medal winners|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/node/5120/|website=British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017|date=27 September 2016}}</ref>

===Sir Israel Gollancz Prize=== {{main|Sir Israel Gollancz Prize}} The '''Sir Israel Gollancz Prize''' was created in 1924 as the '''Biennial Prize for English Literature'''. The name was changed to honour [[Israel Gollancz]] after his death in 1930. It is "is awarded biennially for work connected with Anglo-Saxon, Early English Language and Literature, English Philology, or the History of English Language". It is worth £400.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sir Israel Gollancz Prize|url=http://www.britac.ac.uk/sir-israel-gollancz-prize|website=British Academy|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref>
=== Wiley Prize in Economics === The Wiley Prize in Economics was established in 2013 and is sponsored by the publisher [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]]; awarded annually, it recognises "achievement in research by an outstanding early career economist." The recipient is awarded £5,000.<ref name=":2">[https://www.britac.ac.uk/wiley-prize-psychology "Wiley Prize in Psychology"], ''British Academy''. Retrieved 13 May 2018.</ref>
'''List of recipients''' * 2018: Dr [[Mirko Draca]], University of Warwick<ref name="winners 2018"/> * 2017: Dr [[Matthew Elliott (economist)|Matthew Elliott]], University of Cambridge * 2016: Professor [[James Fenske]], University of Warwick * 2015: Dr [[Johannes Spinnewijn]], London School of Economics and Political Science * 2014: Dr [[Vasco Carvalho]], University of Cambridge * 2013: Professor [[Philipp Kircher]], University of Edinburgh
=== Wiley Prize in Psychology === The Wiley Prize in Psychology was established in 2009 and is made in partnership with the publisher Wiley; awarded annually, it recognises "lifetime achievement by an outstanding international scholar and promising early-career work by a UK-based psychologist, within 5 years of receipt of their doctorate." The award is given out to the former in odd years and the latter in even years. The recipient is awarded £5,000.<ref name=":2" />

{{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} '''Besharmi Morcha''', also known as "Slutwalk arthaat Besharmi Morcha", is the Indian equivalent of [[SlutWalk]]. This was an organization started in 2011 by Canadian women who protested Toronto's police public statements suggesting that women could avoid rape and sexual assault by the way they dressed.<ref name="Sarah Bell uk-13739876">{{cite news| last= Bell| first= Sarah| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13739876| title= Slutwalk London: 'Yes means yes and no means no'| work= [[BBC News]]| date= June 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name="SlutWalk homepage">{{cite web| url= http://www.slutwalktoronto.com/| title= homepage| publisher= SlutWalk Toronto| accessdate = May 8, 2011}}</ref> They have conducted events across the world for education about this issue.
The first Besharmi Morcha took place in [[Bhopal]] on 17 July 2011,<ref name="Bhopal001">{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/India/Bhopal-Besharmi-Morcha-gets-lukewarm-response/Article1-722532.aspx |title=Bhopal Besharmi Morcha gets lukewarm response |work=Hindustan Times |date=18 July 2011 |agency=HT Media Limited |author=Pereira, Aaron |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68Dk3zvqO?url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/India/Bhopal-Besharmi-Morcha-gets-lukewarm-response/Article1-722532.aspx |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> followed by Besharmi Morcha [[Delhi]] on 31 July 2011.<ref name="BBCHindi">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/hindi/india/2011/07/110731_slutwalk_delhi_vk.shtml |title=दिल्ली में निकला बेशर्मी मोर्चा – Shamelessly out front in Delhi |work=BBC हिंदी – BBC Hindi |date=31 July 2011 |agency=BBC |author=विनीत खरे – Vineet Khare |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DuG2MqA?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/hindi/india/2011/07/110731_slutwalk_delhi_vk.shtml |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Besharmi Morcha [[Lucknow]] took place on 21 August 2011.<ref name="Lucknow001">{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article2380885.ece |title=After Delhi, Bhopal, Slutwalk makes its Lucknow debut |work=The Hindu |date=22 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68FEvVoIF?url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article2380885.ece |archivedate=7 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Lucknow002">{{cite web |url=http://www.newkerala.com/news/2011/worldnews-52108.html |title=Slutwalk in Lucknow |publisher=NKDC Media Solutions |work=NewKerala.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68FKI87li?url=http://www.newkerala.com/news/2011/worldnews-52108.html |archivedate=7 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Besharmi Morcha [[Bangalore]], coordinated to coincide with similar events in [[Singapore]], [[Kuala Lumpur]] and [[Hong Kong]] on 4 December 2011, was cancelled by police after they received objections.<ref name="BangalorePolice001">{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/karnataka/why-bangalore-cops-cancelled-permission-for-slutwalk-155371 |title=Why Bangalore cops cancelled permission for SlutWalk |work=NDTV.com |date=9 December 2011 |agency=NDTV Convergence Limited |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DtEbrXq?url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/karnataka/why-bangalore-cops-cancelled-permission-for-slutwalk-155371 |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> A police spokesperson said that groups opposing Besharmi Morcha had "threatened to hold a ‘violent protest’".<ref name="BangalorePolice2">{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/bangalore/report_slutwalk-cancelled-as-they-had-it-coming_1621500 |title=SlutWalk cancelled as they had it coming |work=DNA Daily News And Analysis |date=5 December 2011 |agency=DNA |location=Bangalore |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DtlZSn5?url=http://www.dnaindia.com/bangalore/report_slutwalk-cancelled-as-they-had-it-coming_1621500 |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Dhillan Mowli, one of the organisers, reported that she had been told that the event was “not part of Indian culture.”<ref name="TrustLaw001">{{cite web |url=http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/bangalore-slutwalk-cancelled-as-not-part-of-indian-culture-report |title=Bangalore SlutWalk cancelled as not "part of Indian culture" – Report |publisher=TrustLaw – Thomson Reuters Foundation |accessdate=5 December 2011 |author=Bhalla, Nita |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68FAjimzm?url=http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/bangalore-slutwalk-cancelled-as-not-part-of-indian-culture-report |archivedate=7 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Mowli also said, "The vice-president of a women's organisation called me and said that if any women were seen in skimpy clothing during the Slutwalk, they would be beaten with brooms."<ref name="TrustLaw001" />
Christie Thompson, writing for ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms Magazine]],'' observed "...women aren’t marching for the right to walk down the street dressed in barely-there clothes, as critics suggest. They’re fighting for the right to walk down the street. Period."<ref name="MsMag001">{{cite news |url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/blog/2011/07/06/slutwalk-delhi-starts-immodest-discussion-in-india/ |title=SlutWalk Delhi Starts "Immodest" Discussion in India |work=Ms Magazine |date=6 July 2011 |author=Thompson, Christie |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68Dr48hcK?url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/blog/2011/07/06/slutwalk-delhi-starts-immodest-discussion-in-india/ |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Translation==
Besharmi Morcha ({{lang-hi|बेशर्मी मोर्चा}}) is most often translated into English as "shameless protest" or "shameless front". It has also been translated as “March of the Shameless”<ref name="Reuters001">{{cite news |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/07/31/idINIndia-58547420110731 |title=Hundreds protest rape in conservative India’s toned down "SlutWalk" |work=Reuters India |date=31 July 2011 |agency=TrustLaw – Thomson Reuters Foundation |author=Bhalla, Nita |location=Delhi |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68F8MBUbf?url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/07/31/idINIndia-58547420110731 |archivedate=7 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> and "Shameless Campaign".<ref name="SouthAsiaDaily001">{{cite web |url=http://southasia.typepad.com/south_asia_daily/2011/07/the-not-at-all-slutty-slut-walk-of-bhopal.html |title=The not-at-all slutty Slut Walk of Bhopal |publisher=[[Mayank Chhaya]] |work=Blog: South Asia Daily |date=21 July 2011 |author=Chhaya, Mayank |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68GrcXhWq?url=http://southasia.typepad.com/south_asia_daily/2011/07/the-not-at-all-slutty-slut-walk-of-bhopal.html |archivedate=8 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Besharmi Morcha was chosen as the name in India to address its diverse cultural aspects and languages.<ref name="NameChange001">{{cite web |url=http://www.rememberoursisterseverywhere.com/events/slutwalk-new-delhi |title=Besharmi Morcha, "Shameless Protest" |publisher=rememberoursisterseverywhere.com |date=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68F9NV5vc?url=http://www.rememberoursisterseverywhere.com/events/slutwalk-new-delhi |archivedate=7 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="NameChange002">{{cite news | url=http://news.oneindia.in/2011/06/18/no-slutwalk-in-delhi-as-besharmi-morcha-takes-over-aid0120.html | title=No 'SlutWalk' in Delhi as 'Besharmi Morcha' takes over | work=OneIndia News | agency=Greynium Information Technologies Pvt. Ltd.}}</ref>
The word "[[slut]]" does not translate directly or equivalently into Indian languages such as Hindi. The nearest equivalent direct translation of slut is ''ranɖii'' ({{lang-hi|रंडी}})<ref name="RandiTrans">{{cite web |url=http://en.bab.la/dictionary/hindi-english/%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%82%E0%A4%A1%E0%A5%80 |title=Hindi-English translation for "रंडी" |publisher=bab.la |work=bab.la Dictionary |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68Dld0hS8?url=http://en.bab.la/dictionary/hindi-english/%E0%A4%B0%E0%A4%82%E0%A4%A1%E0%A5%80 |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> meaning "prostitute".<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/15/world/asia/15iht-letter15.html?_r=1 |title=Ready or Not, New Delhi Gets a Women’s Street Protest |work=New York Times |date=14 June 2011 |agency=The New York Times Company |author=NILANJANA S. ROY |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DsCYNub?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/15/world/asia/15iht-letter15.html?_r=1 |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Organizers worried that observers would believe that protesters were identifying as prostitutes, or seeking the right to be prostitutes, rather than protesting to protect women's safety and achieve freedom from sexual violence.
Besharmi ({{lang-hi|बेशर्मी}}) translates as shamelessly, brazenly and even boldly. It may imply a quality of obscenity or obscenely.<ref name="BesharmiTrans001">{{cite web |url=http://dict.hinkhoj.com/shabdkosh.php?word=%E0%A4%AC%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B6%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%80 |title=Get Meaning of besharmi in English. बेशर्मी का मतलब अंग्रेजी में जानिए |publisher=HinKhoj InfoLabs LLP |work=hinkhoj.com Hindi to English dictionary |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DpH6jjP?url=http://dict.hinkhoj.com/shabdkosh.php?word=%E0%A4%AC%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B6%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%80 |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Morcha ({{lang-hi|मोर्चा}}) is closely linked to the idea of protest and action. It often indicates political protest and has military overtones.<ref name="MorchaDictionary">{{cite web |url=http://dict.hinkhoj.com/words/meaning-of-%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE-in-english.html |title=Get Meaning of morcha in English. मोर्चा का मतलब अंग्रेजी में जानिए |publisher=HinKhoj InfoLabs LLP |work=hinkhoj.com Hindi to English dictionary |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68DkyWkx2?url=http://dict.hinkhoj.com/words/meaning-of-%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE-in-english.html |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="MorchaDictionary2">{{cite web |url=http://en.bab.la/dictionary/hindi-english/%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE |title=Hindi-English translation for "मोर्चा" |publisher=bab.la |work=bab.la Dictionary |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68Dm01u3N?url=http://en.bab.la/dictionary/hindi-english/%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%9A%E0%A4%BE |archivedate=6 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Besharmi Morcha has multiple meanings that are not readily translated into English. It is generally summed up as meaning "shamelessly and boldly protesting in a united way that others may see as wrong or even obscene".

Wholesale | products = Books, [[Maps]] | revenue = {{decrease}} [[Pound Sterling|£]]54.2 million (2014){{cite news|last=Shaffi|first=Sarah|title=Blackwell's returns to profit|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwells-returns-profit|accessdate=1 March 2015|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=2 October 2014}} | operating_income = {{increase}} [[Pound Sterling|£]]600,000 (2014) | net_income = | num_employees = 1,000 | homepage = [http://www.Blackwells.co.uk/ www.Blackwells.co.uk] | location_city = [[Broad Street, Oxford|Oxford]] | location_country = England, UK | locations = 45 stores (2012){{cite web|title=Our Shops|url=http://bookshop.blackwell.co.uk/jsp/editorial/shops/index.jsp?route=shops|work=Blackwells Online|accessdate=1 February 2012}} | foundation = 1879 }} '''Blackwell UK''', also known as '''Blackwell's''' and '''Blackwell Group''', is a British [[Academic publishing|academic]] [[bookselling|book]] retailer and library supply service. It was founded in 1879 by [[Benjamin Henry Blackwell]], after whom the chain is named, in [[Oxford]] on [[Broad Street, Oxford|Broad Street]]. The firm now has a chain of 45 shops, and an accounts and library supply service. It employs around 1000 staff in its divisions.{{cite news|last=Finch|first=Julia|title=Blackwell book chain owner plans to hand firm over to staff|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/sep/08/blackwells-bookstores-staff-ownership-switch|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 September 2010}}{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Lisa|title=Blackwell cuts 19 from library supply business|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwell-cuts-19-library-supply-business.html|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=10 May 2011}} The Broad Street branches, which include speciality music and [[art book|art/poster]] shops, remained the only ones until expansion in the early 1990s, when at peak after taking over '''Heffers''' in [[Cambridge]] in 1999{{cite news|title=Blackwell's rationalises Heffers Branches|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-miscellaneous/4668559-1.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|year=1999|agency=AllBusiness}} and [[James Thin]] in Scotland in 2002,{{cite news|last=Cave|first=Andrew|title=Blackwell wins Thin in family feud lull|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2760473/Blackwell-wins-Thin-in-family-feud-lull.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=20 April 2002}} the company had over 70 outlets. Its library supply chain serves an international market, but parts were sold off in 2009, with the [[United States|North American]] arm of '''Blackwell Book Services''' and the Australian business James Bennett sold to [[Baker & Taylor]] for their academic arm YBP Library Services.{{cite news|last=Neilan|first=Catherine|title=Blackwell Sells Library supply arm|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwell-sells-us-library-supply-arm.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=8 December 2009}} The group were also publishers, under the [[Blackwell publishing]] imprint which published over 800 journals when it was sold to [[John Wiley & Sons]] in 2007 for £572 million to form [[Wiley-Blackwell]].{{cite news|last=Osborne|first=Alistair|title=Blackwell duo bury hatchet as publisher is sold to John Wiley|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2950888/Blackwell-duo-bury-hatchet-as-publisher-is-sold-to-John-Wiley.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=18 November 2006}} The Blackwell family have run the company since its foundation, with an [[Share (finance)|ownership]] divided between voting shares owned by the family and wealth shares owned by family and others.{{cite news|last=Denny|first=Neill|title=Blackwell's to close head office, as power shifts to staff|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwells-close-head-office-power-shifts-staff.html|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=8 September 2010}} However, there was a public dispute in 2002 between Julian 'Toby' Blackwell, the current owner of the group, and Nigel Blackwell, the former chairman of the publishing arm, about the possible sale of the publishing business. This led to an offer of £300 million from [[Taylor & Francis]]{{cite news|last=Bowers|first=Simon|title=Blackwell's journal of disquiet|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2002/jan/23/books.highereducation?INTCMP=SRCH|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=23 January 2002}} and to an eventual deal with John Wiley & Son in 2006, as a result of which Nigel Blackwell and Toby's son Philip Blackwell left the business,{{cite news|last=Wallows|first=Harry|title=Blackwell's starts fresh chapter|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2930472/Blackwells-starts-fresh-chapter.html|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=20 January 2006}} leaving Toby Blackwell the sole family member still involved in running the company. Other family voting shares are held by a [[Trust law|trust]], which Toby's shares will transfer to when he dies, eventually bringing an end to the Blackwell family involvement with the company.{{cite news|last=Denny|first=Neill|title=Last King of Blackwell's|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/profile/last-king-blackwells.html|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=28 May 2009}} Toby Blackwell announced in 2009 that the wealth shares would be distributed between staff, transforming the company into an [[Employee Share Ownership Plan|employee-partnership]], similar to that of retailer [[John Lewis Partnership|John Lewis]], when the company returns to profitability having spent several years experiencing losses.{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Lisa|title=Blackwell Group halves losses within a year|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwell-group-halves-losses-within-year.html|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=31 March 2011}} The company reported it was expecting to return to profit in 2012. On 29 October 2012,[http://www.thebookseller.com/news/last-minute-delay-uk-nook-launch.html ''Last-minute delay to UK Nook launch'', Lisa Campbell, The Bookseller, London]. Retrieved 8 December 2012. Blackwell's was – with [[Foyles]], [[John Lewis Partnership|John Lewis department stores]], [[Waitrose]], [[Sainsbury's]] and [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]] – among the retailers to launch the [[Barnes & Noble Nook|Nook]] [[E-book reader|e-reader]] – and from, November, the [[Nook HD]] and [[Nook HD+]] tablet computers.[https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-09/26/barnes--noble-nook-launch ''Barnes & Noble's Nook HD and HD+ tablets will come to UK in November'', Ian Steadman, wired.co.uk, 26 September,2012] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121204004015/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-09/26/barnes--noble-nook-launch |date=4 December 2012 }}. Retrieved 8 December 2012. ==History== [[File:Blackwell's Bookshop and White Horse, Broad Street Oxford, September 1977.jpg|thumb|The main store in Oxford in 1977]] The company was founded in 1879 by [[Benjamin Henry Blackwell]], son of the first city librarian, who having finished his education at 13, was apprenticed to a local bookseller for a [[£sd|shilling]] a week. His father, Benjamin Harris Blackwell, had been heavily involved in the [[Temperance movement|Temperance Society]]. The society promoted, as well as religion, self-education and also encouraged reading. The society provided separate rooms for non-alcoholic refreshment and silent reading. A religious family, the Blackwells had also become involved with the Temperance Society due to Benjamin's father being [[teetotal]], and as a protest against the government making money from the [[excise duty]] on alcohol.{{cite web|title=48 – 51 Broad Street, Oxford|url=http://www.headington.org.uk/oxon/broad/buildings/north/48,49,50,51.htm|work=Broad Street Oxford|publisher=Headington|accessdate=27 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702063215/http://headington.org.uk/oxon/broad/buildings/north/48%2C49%2C50%2C51.htm|archivedate=2 July 2011|df=}} The flagship shop at 48–51 [[Broad Street, Oxford]], was originally only twelve feet square but quickly grew to incorporate the upstairs, cellar and neighbouring shops. Benjamin Henry Blackwell was well respected in Oxford and was elected the first [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] councillor for Oxford North. [[Basil Blackwell]], Benjamin Henry's son, became the first Blackwell to go to university; he was awarded a scholarship at [[Oxford University]]'s [[Merton College, Oxford|Merton College]]. He was expected to join the family firm, however, which he did in 1913, after a spell as an apprentice publisher in London. He was tasked with expanding his father's publishing business. [[File:Norrington room.jpg|thumb|left|The "Norrington Room", contains more than 160,000 books on 3+ miles of shelving]] The first Blackwell publication, ''Mensæ Secundæ: verses written in [[Balliol College, Oxford|Balliol College]]'' by [[H.C. Beeching]], was printed in 1897. Blackwell's began the careers of many writers: [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s first poem, "Goblin's Feet", was published in 1915. To promote universal access to literature, Blackwell's pioneered a series of cheaper books, from a one-volume [[Shakespeare]] to "[[£sd|3-and-6]] novels". The publishing company was merged into the main company in 1921, and a scientific section was added in 1939. When Benjamin Henry died in 1924, Basil Blackwell took over from his father, and went on to head the company for over sixty years. Basil Blackwell also wanted to preserve fine printing. After rescuing the Shakespeare Head Press, he commissioned [[belles-lettres]], including well-known classics such as the [[Pilgrim's Progress]], the works of the [[Brontë]]s and a complete version of [[Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer]]'s [[Canterbury Tales]]. In 1966, the Norrington Room was opened, named after [[Arthur Lionel Pugh Norrington|Sir Arthur Norrington]], the President of [[Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]] and extending under part of Trinity College. It boasts three miles (5 km) of shelving and at {{convert|10000|sqft|m2}} merited an entry in the ''[[Guinness Book of Records]]'' as the largest single room selling books.{{cite book|title=The Guinness Book of Records|year=1967|publisher=Guinness Superlatives Limited|location=London|isbn=0-900424-00-1|page=123|edition=14th}} ===Recent history=== The company has followed a determined policy since the 1990s to spread out from its traditional Oxford base and take on a much broader UK presence. In 1995, Blackwell's became the first bookshop in the UK to allow its customers to purchase online from a catalogue of over 150,000 titles, and opened a flagship shop in London the same year, at 100 [[Charing Cross Road]], which is now one of the company's six most prominent shops. Blackwell's took over the Heffers bookshops in [[Cambridge]] in 1999, and in 2002 acquired the academic bookshops of [[James Thin]] in Scotland. Blackwell's now has over 60 retail outlets across the UK, including a number of medical and other specialist bookshops, and even a shop in [[Aberdeen]] specialising in the [[oil industry]]. Both the Oxford and London flagship shops have won Bookseller of the Year at the [[British Book Awards]]. The company is still in the hands of the Blackwell family. Support for its activities, including Blackwell's Online, is based at Beaver House in Oxford. The company was to be partially funded by Toby Blackwell Limited in 2012.{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Lisa|title=Revenue drops but losses down at Blackwell|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/revenue-drops-losses-down-blackwell.html|accessdate=16 April 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=26 March 2012}} ==Locations== Blackwell's maintains over 40 retail outlets across the UK, with flagship stores located in [[Oxford]], [[Cambridge]], [[South Bridge, Edinburgh|Edinburgh]] and [[High Holborn|London]]. Other branches are located on university campuses or are specialist branches, focusing on Music and Art. ===Gallery=== Image:Blackwell bookstore.jpg|Flagship branch, 48-51 [[Broad Street, Oxford]] File:Blackwell's. (14604009310).jpg|[[South Bridge, Edinburgh]] File:Blackwell University Bookshop, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds (4th May 2010).jpg|Woodhouse Lane, [[Leeds]] File:Blackwell's University Bookshop - geograph.org.uk - 1027633.jpg|Cambridge Road, [[University of Portsmouth]] File:Blackwell UK Reading.JPG|Whiteknights, [[University of Reading]] File:Blackwells Sheffield.jpg|Portobello Street, [[University of Sheffield]] File:Blackwells, Charing Cross Road.jpg|The former [[Charing Cross Road]] store, London File:Heffer's Bookshop - geograph.org.uk - 1335907.jpg|Heffers Sound, [[Trinity Street, Cambridge]] File:Blackwell UK Music, Broad Street, Oxford.jpg|Blackwell's Music, previously at 23-25 Broad Street, Oxford File:Art poster Blackwells Oxford.jpg|Blackwell's Art and Poster Shop, 27 Broad Street, Oxford ==See also== {{Portal|Companies|Books}} * [[Books in the United Kingdom]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Blackwell UK}} * [http://www.blackwell.co.uk/ Blackwell Online] * [https://twitter.com/blackwellbooks Blackwell Twitter] * [http://www.oxfordcityguide.com/TouristInfo/SightSeeing.html Photo and other information on OxfordCityGuide.com] {{Bookstore Chains}} [[Category:Retail companies established in 1879]] [[Category:Book publishing companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Shops in Oxford]] [[Category:Privately held companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Bookshops of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Book selling websites]] [[Category:Companies based in Oxford]] [[Category:British brands]] [[Category:Book distributors]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Use British English|date=December 2016}} '''Charles Bagot Cayley''' (1823–1883) was an English [[linguistics|linguist]], best known for translating [[Dante Alighieri|Dante]] into the metre of the original, with annotations. He also made metrical versions of the ''[[Iliad]]'', the ''[[Prometheus]]'' of [[Aeschylus|Æschylus]], the ''[[Canzoniere]]'' of [[Petrarch]].
The translations from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] are a laboured attempt to mirror the versification rules of the originals. His version of ''[[The Divine Comedy]]'' is much more successful, preserving the Dante's ''[[terza rima]]'' rhyme scheme while using a relatively simple English which reflects Dante's own use of ordinary [[Italian language|Italian]]. Charles Bagot Cayley also published a collection of his own poems, ''Psyche's Interludes''.
From Mr Pollecary's school, Blackheath, Charles Cayley went to [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], graduating in 1845 with a BA in the classical tripos.<ref>{{acad|id=CLY841CB|name=Cayley, Charles Bagot}}</ref> He also studied at [[King's College London]], under [[Gabriele Rossetti]].
In his youth he obtained a post in the Patent Office, but gave this up when he embarked on an early venture into billboard advertising at railway stations. The venture was ahead of its time and he lost most of his money. The rest of his life he spent in relative poverty. The accounts of [[William Michael Rossetti]] (brother of Christina) portray him as a shy and unworldly intellectual with a cerebral sense of humour. He was a leading figure in the [[London]] [[Philological Society]]. He is said to have been asked by the [[SPCK]] to translate the New Testament into [[Iroquoian languages|Iroquois]]; not knowing Iroquois, he allegedly learnt sufficient of the language in one month to be able to complete the task. He was born in [[Saint Petersburg|St Petersburg]], the son of a [[Russia]]n merchant. He fell in love with the poet [[Christina Rossetti]] but she felt unable to marry him because he was an [[Agnosticism|agnostic]] (she was a [[High Church]] [[Anglicanism|Anglican]]). They remained close friends until his death, and several of her poems were written with him in mind. His brother was the mathematician [[Arthur Cayley]].
